{{Infobox writer | name = George Seldes | image = George Seldes.GIF | imagesize = | caption = George Seldes (1989), age 98 | pseudonym = | birth_name = Henry George Seldes | birth_date = {{birth date|1890|11|16}} | birth_place = [[Alliance Colony]], [[New Jersey]], USA
(now [[Vineland, New Jersey]]) | death_date = {{Death date and age|1995|7|2|1890|11|16}} | death_place = [[Windsor, Vermont]], USA | occupation = Author, Journalist | language = English | nationality = American | notableworks = {{Collapsible list |title= ''See list of books'' |''You Can't Print That!: The Truth Behind the News, 1918–1928'' |''Can These Things Be!'' |''World Panorama'' |''Sawdust Caesar: The Untold History of Mussolini and Fascism'' |''You Can't Do That'' |''The Facts Are: A Guide to Falsehood and Propaganda in the Press and Radio'' |''Facts and Fascism'' |''The People Don't Know: The American Press and the Cold War''}} | spouse = Helen Larkin Seldes, née Wiesman (1932-1979; her death) | parents = | children = | relatives = [[Gilbert Seldes]] (brother)
[[Marian Seldes]] (niece) | website = {{URL|georgeseldes.net}} }} '''Henry George Seldes'''{{cite web |url=http://www.hermes-press.com/seldes_index.htm |title=Speaking Truth to Power |last1=Lovegood |first1=Norman D. |date= |website=Hermes Press |publisher= |accessdate=September 22, 2014}} ({{IPAc-en|'|s|E|l|d|@|s}} {{respell|SEL|dəs}};{{Ref label|aaa|aa}}{{cite book|last1=Seldes|first1=George|title=Great Thoughts, Revised and Updated|date=2011|publisher=Random House Publishing Group|pages=Forward|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZirsLPyzJEgC|accessdate=3 August 2014}} November 16, 1890 – July 2, 1995) was an American [[investigative journalist]], [[foreign correspondent]], editor, author, and media critic best known for the publication of the newsletter ''In Fact'' from 1940 to 1950. He was an investigative reporter of the kind known in early 20th century as a [[muckraker]], using his journalism to fight injustice and justify reform. But by his time the public mood had changed, and reader demand for muckraking was much weaker. According to historian Helen Fordham, Seldes's career demonstrates how those who crusaded too vehemently seemed to violate new standards of impartiality and objectivity. His work was often criticized as too radical.{{cite journal |last = Fordham |first = Helen |date = November 17, 2016 |title = Subversive Voices: George Seldes and Mid-Twentieth-Century Muckraking |url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08821127.2016.1241643 |journal = American Journalism |volume = 33 |issue = 4 |pages = 424–441 |doi = 10.1080/08821127.2016.1241643 |access-date = January 29, 2017}} Influenced by [[Lincoln Steffens]] and [[Walter Lippmann]],{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/details/americanjournali13amer |date=Winter 1996 |title=American journalism |publisher=American Journalism Historians Association |pages=11}}{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0eHB6xgXgHgC |last=Seldes |first=George |title=China Monthly Review, Volume 76 |location=East Asia |publisher=[[John W. Powell]] |pages=106 |quote=I agree with Walter Lippmann who a decade ago wrote that the crisis of democracy is a crisis in journalism, and again I agree that 'those who think the sole cause is corruption,' are wrong.}} Seldes's career began when he was hired at the ''[[Pittsburgh Leader]]'' at the age of 19. In 1914, he was appointed night editor of the ''[[Pittsburgh Post]]''. In 1916, he went to the [[United Press]] in London. In 1917, during World War I, he moved to France to work at the Marshall Syndicate. While there, he interviewed [[Paul von Hindenburg]], the supreme commander of the German Army. Hindenburg commented on Germany's defeat in the war, including U.S. involvement, and the interview was censored by the U. S. military. Seldes later claimed the interview's publication could have prevented the [[Nazis]]' rise to power and thus World War II. After World War I, Seldes spent ten years as a reporter for the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. In 1922, he interviewed [[Vladimir Lenin]], and in 1923 he was expelled from the Soviet Union, along with three colleagues, for disguising news reports as personal letters; a letter his publisher wrote for the Soviets only facilitated his expulsion. The newspaper then sent him to Italy, where he implicated [[Benito Mussolini]] in opposition leader [[Giacomo Matteotti]]'s murder. He was again expelled. In 1927, Seldes reported for the ''Chicago Tribune'' in Mexico, where he criticized the use of the country's mineral rights by American companies. He battled with the ''Tribune's'' owner and publisher, Colonel Robert McCormick, over the paper's altering of his Mexico articles, and soon afterward quit the ''Tribune'' over what he considered to be censorship. In 1929, Seldes became a freelance reporter and author, subsequently writing [[#Works|a series of books]] [[#Freelance|and criticism]] about his years as a foreign correspondent, and the issues of censorship, suppression and distortion in the press. During the late 1930s he had one more stint as a foreign correspondent, with his wife Helen, for the New York ''Post'', in Spain during the [[Spanish Civil War]]. In 1940, Seldes co-founded a weekly newsletter, [[#In Fact|''In Fact'']], subtitled "an Antidote to Falsehoods in the Daily Press." In it, he attacked corporate malfeasance, often using government documents from the [[Federal Trade Commission]] (FTC) and the [[Federal Communications Commission]] (FCC). He exposed the health hazards of cigarettes and attacked the mainstream press for suppressing them, blaming the newspapers' heavy dependence on cigarette advertising. He cited [[J. Edgar Hoover]] and the [[FBI]] for anti-union campaigns, and brought attention to the [[National Association of Manufacturers]]' use of advertising dollars to produce news stories favorable to its members and suppress unfavorable ones. [[#Critical reception|Having both staunch admirers and strong critics]], Seldes influenced some younger journalists. He received an award for professional excellence from the [[Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication|Association for Education in Journalism]] in 1980 and a [[George Polk Award]] for his life's work in 1981. Seldes also served on the board of [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting]] (FAIR). ==Family== The writer and critic [[Gilbert Seldes]] was George Seldes's younger brother. Actress [[Marian Seldes]] was his niece; his nephew was the literary agent Timothy Seldes. He was married to Helen Larkin Seldes, née Wiesman, from 1932 to her death in 1979. ==Early years== Henry George Seldes, named after economist [[Henry George]], was born on November 16, 1890, to ethnic Jewish émigrés from Russia in [[Alliance Colony]], an agricultural community in rural southern New Jersey.{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=1265&letter=A&search=alliance%20colony |title=Alliance |last1=Reis |first1=J. C. |work=Jewish Encyclopedia |publisher=JewishEncyclopedia.com |location=West Conshohocken, PA |accessdate=March 31, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/5317/fund-raising-effort-sends-local-filmmaker-to-the-oscars/ |title=Fund-raising effort sends local filmmaker to the Oscars |last1=Pearl |first1=Lesley |date=March 21, 1997 |work=JWeekly.com |publisher=San Francisco Jewish Community Publications Inc |location=San Francisco |accessdate=March 31, 2011}} His mother, Anna Saphro, died in 1896 when he and his younger brother, Gilbert, were still young.{{cite book |last=Kammen |first=Michael |date=March 1996 |title=The Lively Arts: Gilbert Seldes and the Transformation of Cultural Criticism in the United States |url= |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |page=17 |isbn=0-19-509868-4 |accessdate= }} George's father, George Sergius Seldes, was a pharmacist and a strongly opinionated and radically philosophical man who was a libertarian and corresponded with [[Leo Tolstoy]] and [[Peter Kropotkin]], being interested in the latter's ideas on [[Mutual Aid: A Factor of Evolution|mutual aid]]. He influenced every aspect of his sons' lives, pushing them to "read books that you will reread—and that you will never outgrow," and refusing to force religion upon children who were "too young to understand it," instilling a free-thinking attitude in his sons.{{cite book |last=Kammen |first=Michael |date=March 1996 |title=The Lively Arts: Gilbert Seldes and the Transformation of Cultural Criticism in the United States |url= |location=Oxford |publisher=Oxford University Press |pages=18–19 |isbn=0-19-509868-4 |accessdate= }} When he was 19, Seldes went to work at the ''[[Pittsburgh Leader]]''. An early scoop of his for this paper was when two-time presidential candidate [[William Jennings Bryan]] expelled Seldes from Bryan's hotel room. He also interviewed a saleswoman who had filed a rape complaint against the son of the owner on a large [[department store]], but the story was not published, and Seldes became outraged when the advertising department of the newspaper [[blackmail]]ed the owner into buying more advertising. In 1914, he was appointed night editor of the ''[[Pittsburgh Post]]''. As a young journalist, he was influenced by the investigative journalism of [[muckraker]] [[Lincoln Steffens]], whom he met in 1919. ==World War I== In 1916, Seldes moved to London where he worked for the [[United Press]]. When the United States joined the [[First World War]] in 1917, Seldes was sent to France where he worked as the war correspondent for the [[Marshall Syndicate]]. At end of the war, he obtained an exclusive interview with [[Paul von Hindenburg]], the supreme commander of the German Army, in which Hindenburg acknowledged the role America had played in defeating Germany. "The American infantry," said Hindenburg, "won the World War in battle in the Argonne." Seldes and the others were accused of breaking the [[Armistice]] and were [[court martial]]ed. They were also forbidden to write anything about the interview and it never appeared in American news media. Seldes believed that blocking publication of this interview proved tragic. Unaware of Hindenburg's direct testimony of Germany's military defeat, Germans adopted the ''[[Dolchstoss]]'' or "stab-in-the-back" theory that Germany had only lost the war because it was betrayed at home by "the socialists, the Communists and the Jews," which served as [[Nazism]]'s explanation for Germany's defeat. "If the Hindenburg interview had been passed by [[John J. Pershing|Pershing]]'s censors at the time, it would have been headlined in every country civilized enough to have newspapers and undoubtedly would have made an impression on millions of people and became an important page in history," wrote Seldes. "I believe it would have destroyed the main planks on which Hitler rose to power, it would have prevented World War II, the greatest and worst war in all history, and it would have changed the future of all mankind."{{cite book |title=Witness to a Century |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1987 |page=100}}{{cite web |url=http://www.publiceye.org/glossary/seldes.html#fairobit |title=Great Press Critic Leaves a Legacy of Courage |last1=Solomon |first1=Norman |authorlink1=Norman Solomon |last2=Cohen |first2=Jeff |authorlink2=Jeff Cohen (media critic) |date=July 1995 |work=PublicEye.org |publisher=Political Research Associates |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} Seldes claimed that the [[Battle of Saint-Mihiel]] never happened. In his account, General Pershing planned to capture the city, but on September 1 the Germans decided to remove their forces from Saint-Mihiel to reinforce other positions. Seldes claimed no shots were fired as the first Americans, he among them, entered the city on September 13 to be greeted as liberators before General Pershing, [[Philippe Pétain|Pétain]], and other high-ranking officers arrived. The thousands of German prisoners captured, he wrote, were taken as they mistakenly arrived at the train station days later to relieve the German troops that had left days earlier.{{cite book |title=Even the Gods Can't Change History |last=Seldes |first=George |chapter=Chapter 1: First Encounter with the Goddess of History: Saint-Mihiel}} ==Lenin and Mussolini== [[File:George Seldes young.jpg|thumb|right|Picture of a young George Seldes for a ''Chicago Tribune'' filecard. Notice the ''Chicago Tribune'' stamp]] Seldes spent the next ten years as an international reporter for the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]''. He interviewed [[Vladimir Lenin|Lenin]] in 1922. He and three other reporters were expelled in 1923 when Soviet authorities, who routinely censored foreign reporters' telegraphed dispatches, found articles by the four reporters, disguised as personal letters, being smuggled out in a diplomatic mailpouch to avoid censorship. The expulsion was facilitated, according to Seldes, after his publisher, Colonel Robert McCormick, failed to show sufficient respect when writing to the Soviets to protest censorship.{{cite news |title=Letters |last=Colonel McCormick |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert R. McCormick |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,808220-2,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=March 5, 1956 |accessdate=January 11, 2011|display-authors=etal}} The ''Chicago Tribune'' sent him to [[Italy]] where he wrote about [[Benito Mussolini]] and the rise of fascism. (Mussolini had served as Seldes's [[stringer (journalism)|stringer]] before the former took power.{{cite news |last=Guttenplan |first=John |date=July 14, 1995 |title=OBITUARY: George Seldes |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-george-seldes-1591344.html |newspaper=The Independent |location= London |access-date=January 29, 2015}}) He investigated the murder of [[Giacomo Matteotti]], the head of the parliamentary section of the Italian [[Unitary Socialist Party (Italy, 1922)|Unitary Socialist Party]]. His article implicated Mussolini in the killing, and Seldes was expelled from Italy.{{cite news |title=Foreign News: Ousted |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,720698,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=August 10, 1925 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} He wrote an account of Italian censorship and intimidation of American reporters for ''[[Harper's Magazine]]''.{{cite news |title=Italy: Censorship Bared |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,731121,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=October 31, 1927 |accessdate=January 12, 2011}} In 1927, the ''Chicago Tribune'' sent Seldes to [[Mexico]], but his articles criticizing American corporations for their use of that country's [[mineral rights]] were not well received. Seldes returned to Europe, but found that his work increasingly censored to fit the political views of the newspaper's owner, [[Robert R. McCormick]]. ==Freelance== Disillusioned, Seldes left the ''Tribune'' and went to work as a freelance writer. In his first two books, ''You Can't Print That!'' (1929) and ''Can These Things Be!'' (1931), Seldes included material that he had not been allowed to publish in the ''Tribune''. His next book, ''World Panorama'' (1933), was a narrative history of the interbellum period. In 1932 he married Helen Larkin Wiesman (later Seldes), who died in the late 1970s. In 1934, Seldes published a history of the Roman Catholic Church, ''The Vatican''. This was followed by an exposé of the global arms industry, ''Iron, Blood and Profits'' (1934) and an account of Benito Mussolini, ''Sawdust Caesar'' (1935). Two books on the newspaper business established his enduring reputation as a critic of the press: ''Freedom of the Press'' (1935) and ''Lords of the Press'' (1938). He took the title of the latter from a speech by Secretary of the Interior [[Harold L. Ickes|Harold Ickes]]: "Our ancestors did not fight for the right of a few Lords of the Press to have almost exclusive control of and censorship over the dissemination of news and ideas." He believed "that advertisers were a far greater threat to journalistic freedom than government censorship."{{cite news |title=Obituary: George Seldes |last1=Guttenplan |first1=John |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/people/obituary-george-seldes-1591344.html |newspaper=The Independent |date=July 14, 1995 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} The press and news, he wrote, "are coming more and more under the domination of a handful of corporate publishers who may print such news as they wish to print and omit such news as they do not wish to print."{{cite book |title=Communication, Power, and Media |last=Gibson |first=Donald |year=2004 |publisher=Nova Science |location=Hauppauge, NY |page=14}} ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' was initially positive in its response: "A rambling but effective attack on U. S. newspapers, charging coloring, distortion or suppression of vital news, containing some enlightening instances of journalistic malpractices as George Seldes encountered them during his career as correspondent."{{cite news |title=Fiction: Recent Books |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,749111,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=September 23, 1935 |quote=FREEDOM OF THE PRESS—George Seldes—Bobbs-Merrill ($2.75). A rambling but effective attack on U. S. newspapers, charging coloring, distortion or suppression of vital news, containing some enlightening instances of journalistic malpractices as George Seldes encountered them during his career as correspondent. |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} Later, ''Time'' called him a muckraker, meaning a biased and crusading critic, when it called another writer's work "refreshingly fair and accurate (especially in comparison with muckraking books like George Seldes' Lords of the Press)."{{cite news |title=The Press: Howe Behind the News |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,884201,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=November 25, 1940 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} Seldes told of his pursuit of a tobacco study that he would make public years later, though the author of the study denied his account and claimed his work had been widely cited in the press.{{cite news |title=The Press: Suppression of News |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,760627,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=January 23, 1939 |quote=The Seldes book rambles, relies heavily on innuendo. It contains a large store of previously published facts, many a windy, publisher-baiting tirade. |accessdate=January 11, 2011}}{{cite news |title=Contradicts Ickes on Tobacco Story |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1939/01/14/archives/contradicts-ickes-on-tobacco-story-johns-hopkins-biologist-says.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=January 14, 1939 |accessdate=January 12, 2011}} He also reported on the [[Spanish Civil War]] on a freelance basis for three years and later said that American reporters too readily accepted what the Franco side wanted them to believe. On his return to the United States in 1940, Seldes published ''Witch Hunt'', an account of the persecution of people with left-wing political views in America, and ''The Catholic Crisis'', which sought to demonstrate the close relationship between the [[Catholic Church]] and fascist organizations in Europe. When ''Time'' reviewed the latter, it noted several of Seldes' works and said he "stuck out his tongue at Benito Mussolini ... thumbed his nose at U. S. journalism ... and uttered some hoarse Bronx cheers at the Roman Catholic Church." The review complained that his detailed accounts of church activities were "in part damaging" but "not all germane to the subject."{{cite news |title=Religion: Seldes vs. Rome |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,762893,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=November 7, 1929 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} ==''In Fact''== {{redirect|In Fact|the KAT-TUN song|In Fact (song)|a book|In Fact: The Best of Creative Nonfiction}} [[File:Orange-Seldes-In Fact-Draft Dodgers-1600.png|thumb|right|Cover of volume IX of edition 22 of ''In Fact, An Antidote for Falsehood in the Daily Press'']] From 1940 to 1950, Seldes published a political newsletter, ''In Fact'' which originally had the full name ''In Fact: For the millions who want a free press''[https://archive.org/stream/InFactVolume1IssueNumber1/InFactVolINo.1#page/n0/mode/1up ''In Fact'', Volume 1, Issue Number 1] and later ''In Fact: An Antidote for Falsehood in the Daily Press'', "a four-page weekly compendium of news other newspapers wouldn't print." Washington Post editor and later press critic [[Ben Bagdikian]] said, "When Seldes was no longer printed by the mainstream press, he was an important conduit to the journalistic community, who knew that there were flaws in the system, but often couldn't get printed in their own newspapers, because the press cannot be a watchdog on itself. So they fed stories critical of the press to Seldes."{{cite web |url=http://kovnocommunications.org/films/tell-the-truth-and-run/ |title=Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press |author= |website= |publisher=Kovno Communications |accessdate=October 9, 2014}} At the height of its popularity it had a circulation of 176,000. One of the first articles published in the newsletter concerned the dangers of cigarette smoking.{{cite news |title=George Seldes Is Dead at 104; An Early, Fervent Press Critic |last1=Dicke |first1=William |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/07/03/obituaries/george-seldes-is-dead-at-104-an-early-fervent-press-critic.html |newspaper=The New York Times |date=July 3, 1995 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} Seldes later explained that at the time, "The tobacco stories were suppressed by every major newspaper. For ten years we pounded on tobacco as being one of the only legal poisons you could buy in America." At a time when tobacco companies were major advertisers, Seldes discussed the contents of a study called, "Tobacco Smoking and Longevity", which he said had been suppressed since 1939. Throughout the 10-year run of ''In Fact'', Seldes published more than 50 stories on the health effects of tobacco, and the cigarette industry's attempts and suppressing such news. Among the favorite targets of ''In Fact'' was the [[National Association of Manufacturers]]. Defense analyst [[Daniel Ellsberg]], who subscribed to ''In Fact'' while an undergrad at Harvard, said, "I heard about the National Association of Manufacturers first from Seldes and more from Seldes than I ever heard again. If you were to read the mainstream press, you'd hardly become aware that such organizations existed, that businessmen worked together to pursue their own interests." ''In Fact'' also attacked [[Charles Lindbergh]] for his Nazi sympathies, the [[American Legion]] for helping to break strikes, and labeled many captains of industry as "native fascists." Consumer advocate [[Ralph Nader]] said, "[Seldes] used the word fascism to reflect an authoritarian state of mind that tended to stifle free speech and dissent and also tended to believe that might was right." ''In Fact'' immediately attracted the attention of government authorities. President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt|Roosevelt]] ordered an FBI investigation of Seldes and ''In Fact'' in 1940.{{cite journal |last1=O'Reilly |first1=Kenneth |year=1982 |title=A New Deal for the FBI: The Roosevelt Administration, Crime Control, and National Security |journal=Journal of American History |volume=69 |issue=649 |pages= 638|publisher= |doi= 10.2307/1903141|url= |accessdate= }} Articles claiming that the FBI was infiltrating unions and monitoring union activities resulted in FBI surveillance of Seldes and his publication. [[J. Edgar Hoover]] sent Seldes a 15-page letter denying such FBI activities.{{cite journal |last1=Lasar |first1=Matthew |year=1998 |title='Right Out in Public': Pacifica Radio, the Cold War, and the Political Origins of Alternative Media |journal=Pacific Historical Review |volume=67 |issue=537 |pages= 513–541|publisher= |doi= 10.2307/3641185|url= |accessdate= }} The FBI subsequently questioned ''In Fact'' subscribers, particularly servicemen and women, and had US postal officials reporting to the FBI on Seldes' mail correspondence. ''In Fact'' lost many of its subscribers in the late 1940s. Seldes later claimed that his critical coverage of Yugoslavia got the publication banned from Communist Party bookstores. The political climate discouraged subscriptions on the part of less ideologically committed readers as well. ''In Fact'' ceased publication in 1950. ''[[I. F. Stone|I. F. Stone's Weekly]]'', which started publication in 1953, took ''In Fact'' as its model. In addition to writing his newsletter, Seldes continued to publish books. These included ''Facts and Fascism'' (1943) and ''One Thousand Americans'' (1947), an account of the people who controlled America. ''Time'' called ''One Thousand Americans'' "a collection of truths, half-truths and untruths about the U.S. press and industry."{{cite news |title=The Press: The Beaver's World |url= http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,798474-2,00.html|newspaper=TIME |date=April 26, 1948 |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} ''One Thousand Americans'' introduced a wide audience to the [[Business Plot]], a supposed plan of America's corporate elite to overthrow the U.S. government in the early 1930s.{{cite book |title=One Thousand Americans |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1947 |publisher=Boni & Gaer |location=New York |isbn= |pages=79, 179–80, 208–10, 287–92 |url= |accessdate=}} Seldes published ''The People Don't Know'' on the origins of the [[Cold War]] in 1949. ==Politics and later career== According to KGB documents, Seldes was a longtime secret member of the [[CPUSA|Communist Party]] since well before 1940, valued for his "major connections" in Washington.{{cite book |title=Spies: The Rise and Fall of the KGB in America |last1=Haynes |first1=John Earl |authorlink1=John Earl Haynes |last2=Vassiliev |first2=Alexander |authorlink2=Alexander Vassiliev |last3=Klehr |first3=Harvey |authorlink3=Harvey Klehr |year=2009 |publisher=Yale University Press |location=New Haven |isbn=0-300-12390-6 |page=169 |pages= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qCAVQ_cdomcC |accessdate=January 9, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/topics/docs/Black%20Notebook%20Translated1.pdf |title=Black Notebook |last1=Vassiliev |first1=Alexander |last2=Redko |first2=Philip |last3=Haynes |first3=John Earl |date=January 9, 2011 |work= |publisher=Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars |page=512 |accessdate=January 9, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100711055816/http://www.wilsoncenter.org/topics/docs/Black%20Notebook%20Translated1.pdf |archivedate=July 11, 2010 |df= }} Seldes later wrote that ''In Fact'' was founded at the instigation of the U.S. Communist Party leadership, but he wrote that the Party worked through his partner Bruce Minton (also known as Richard Bransten) without his knowledge. Seldes wrote that he was unaware that Minton was a Party member who received the funds to start ''In Fact'' from Communist Party.{{Ref label|aab|ab}}{{cite book |title=Never Tire of Protesting |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1968 |publisher=L. Stuart |location=New York |isbn= |pages=53, 56, 195, 197, 198, 200, 201, 203, 204}} While his political positions often were similar to those in the Party in 1940, by 1948 Seldes was writing in positive terms of the [[Titoism|anti-Soviet communism]] of [[Marshal Tito]] in Yugoslavia, earning him the wrath of many Communist Party loyalists in the United States. As the [[Cold War]] took shape at the end of the decade, Seldes lost readership from both the Communists and the anti-liberal-left sentiment that was sweeping the country, including a trade union movement that had contained some of his largest audience.{{cite book |last=Seldes |first=George |authorlink= |title=Never Tire of Protesting |url= |accessdate= |year=1968 |publisher=L. Stuart |location=New York |isbn= |page=}} The nationwide atmosphere of [[McCarthyism]] and [[red-baiting]] further diminished his subscribers' numbers, and he was financially forced to close ''In Fact'', which never accepted advertising, in October 1950. Senator [[Joseph McCarthy]] subpoenaed Seldes in 1953, Seldes vehemently denied [[CPUSA|Communist Party]] membership and was "cleared" by McCarthy's Senate subcommittee, but Seldes's greatest influence on readers had already passed.{{cite news |title=Letters |first=George |last=Seldes |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,819887-2,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=May 31, 1954 |accessdate=January 11, 2011|display-authors=etal}} Seldes did publish ''Tell the Truth and Run'' in 1953, but otherwise found it difficult to publish his work throughout the 1950s. He was approached, however, by an old friend and colleague, I.F. Stone, for advice on how to start a small independent investigative newspaper. ''I.F. Stone's Weekly'' premiered in 1953, picking up where Seldes had left off.{{cite AV media |last=Goldsmith |first=Rick |year=1996 |title=Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press |trans-title=|medium= |url= |accessdate=August 18, 2013 |format= |time= |publisher=Kovno Communications |location= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |quote= |ref= }} Largely dropping his own writing, he developed an anthology called ''The Great Quotations'' and received rejections from 20 publishers. It sold more than a million copies when it appeared in 1961. In a letter to ''Time'' magazine in 1974, he appraised the state of American journalism as much improved in his lifetime:{{cite news |title=Letters |first=George |last=Seldes |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,911431,00.html |newspaper=TIME |date=July 29, 1974 |accessdate=January 11, 2011|display-authors=etal}}
The press deserved the attacks and criticisms of [[Will Irwin]] (1910) and [[Upton Sinclair]] (1920) and the muckrakers who followed, and it needs today the watchdog and gadfly activities of the new critical weeklies, but all in all it is now a better medium of mass information ... The 1972 [[Watergate]] disclosures, it is true, were made by only a score of the members of the mass media, but I remember [[Teapot Dome]] when only one of our 1,750 dailies (the Albuquerque Morning Journal) dared to tell the truth about White House corruption. We have come a long way since.
He published ''Never Tire of Protesting'' in 1968 and ''Even the Gods Can't Change History'' in 1976. The [[Association for Education in Journalism and Mass Communication|Association for Education in Journalism]] gave him an award for professional excellence in 1980. In 1981 he received the [[George Polk Award]] for his life's work.{{cite web |url=http://www.liu.edu/About/News/Polk/Previous.aspx |title=Previous Award Winners |work= |publisher=Long Island University |accessdate=January 16, 2011}} He published his autobiography, ''Witness to a Century'' in 1987. He wrote: "And so [my brother] Gilbert and I, brought up without a formal religion, remained throughout our lifetimes just what Father was, freethinkers. And, likewise, doubters and dissenters and perhaps Utopians. Father's rule had been 'Question everything, take nothing for granted,' and I never outlived it, and I would suggest it be made the motto of a world journalists' association." In 1981, Seldes appeared in [[Warren Beatty]]'s ''[[Reds (film)|Reds]]'', a film about the life of journalist [[John Reed (journalist)|John Reed]]. Seldes appears as one of the film's "witnesses" commenting on the historical events depicted in the film. Seldes served on the board of [[Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting]] (FAIR).{{cite web |url=http://www.publiceye.org/glossary/seldes.html#chipobit |title=Press Critic and Antifascist George Seldes Dies at 104 in Vermont |last1=Berlet |first1=Chip |authorlink=Chip Berlet |work=PublicEye.org |publisher=Political Research Associates |accessdate=January 12, 2011}} Martin A. Lee and Norman Solomon used a quote from Seldes as an epigraph for their book ''Unreliable Sources'': "The most sacred cow of the press is the press itself."{{cite book |title=Unreliable Sources: A Guide to Detecting Bias in the Media |last1=Lee |first1=Martin A. |authorlink1=Martin A. Lee |last2=Solomon |first2=Norman |authorlink2=Norman Solomon |year=1990 |publisher=Carol Publishers |location=New York |isbn= |page= |pages= |url= |accessdate=}} ==Death and legacy== Seldes died on July 2, 1995, in [[Windsor, Vermont]]. He was 104. A delegation of journalists attended the memorial service at his home in [[Hartland, Vermont|Hartland-4-Corners, Vermont]], read from his books and watched an excerpt from ''[[Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press]],'' a documentary in progress.{{cite web |url=http://www.publiceye.org/glossary/seldes.html#seldcomm |title=Seldes Remembrance Committee |last1=Solomon |first1=Norman |authorlink1=Norman Solomon |last2=Cohen |first2=Jeff |authorlink2=Jeff Cohen (media critic) |work=PublicEye.org |publisher=Political Research Associates |accessdate=January 11, 2011}} The documentary was produced and directed by Rick Goldsmith and premiered the following year, in 1996.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0117873/|title=Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press (1996)|work=|publisher=Internet Movie Database|accessdate=January 11, 2011}} It covered Seldes's life and career, and revived the life and work of a man who for four decades had been largely forgotten. The film looked at Seldes's life and work, especially the theme of censorship and suppression in America's news media. It was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Documentary Feature, and received many other accolades, including the John O'Connor Film Award from the American Historical Association.{{cite web |url=http://www.historians.org/prizes/awarded/OconnorWinner.cfm |title=John E. O'Connor Film Award |author= |date=March 25, 2013 |website= |publisher=American Historical Association |accessdate=August 15, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://www.brasscheck.com/seldes/ |title=Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press |author= |website= |publisher=Brasscheck |accessdate=August 15, 2013}}{{cite web |url=http://kovnocommunications.org/films/tell-the-truth-and-run/ |title=Tell the Truth and Run: George Seldes and the American Press |author= |website= |publisher=Kovno Communications |accessdate=August 15, 2013}} ==Critical reception== Seldes had both staunch admirers and strong critics. Some of his contemporaries and later historians have judged much of his work harshly. One critic thought [[I. F. Stone]] "was light years beyond Seldes."{{cite journal |last1=Boylan |first1=James |last2=Cottrell |first2=Robert C. |year=1993 |title=Izzy: A Biography of I.F. Stone |journal=Journal of American History |volume=80 |issue=1157-8 |pages= 1157|publisher=Oxford University Press and Organization of American Historians |doi= 10.2307/2080554|url= |accessdate= }} Others cited his political bias and preconceptions. A study of the Dies Committee said that Seldes's account in ''Witch Hunt'' suffered from his view that everything the Committee did was wrong.{{cite book |title=The Dies Committee: A Study of the Special House Committee for the Investigation of Un-American Activities, 1938–1944 |last=Ogden |first=August Raymond |year=1943 |publisher=Catholic University of America Press |location=Washington, DC |isbn= |pages=55, 64, 84}} Another warned that ''The Catholic Crisis'' "should be read with great caution in view of the author's latent anti-Catholic and pro-Communist bias."{{cite journal |last1=Eulau |first1=Heinz |year=1947 |title=Proselytizing in the Catholic Press |journal=Public Opinion Quarterly |volume=1 |issue= |pages=195 |publisher= |doi= 10.1086/265843|url= |accessdate= }} Another cited Seldes as a writer with "an agenda."{{cite encyclopedia |last=Jenkins |first=Philip |encyclopedia=Pennsylvania History |title='It Can't Happen Here': Fascism and Right-Wing Extremism in Pennsylvania, 1933–1942 |trans-title=|url= |accessdate= |language= |edition= |year=1995 |publisher= |volume=62 |location= |id= |isbn= |oclc= |doi= |pages=52 |quote= |ref= }} Still another evaluated ''Iron, Blood, and Profits'' as "less sober" than other works on the subject of international arms dealing.{{cite encyclopedia |last=Langer |first=William W. |year=1934 |title=Some Recent Books on International Relations |encyclopedia=Foreign Affairs |publisher= |volume=12 |location= |id= |pages=690}} Of his biography of Mussolini, another wrote: "many of his sources were unreliable and his book was almost devoid of logical order."{{cite journal |last1=Detzell |first1=Charles F. |year=1963 |title=Benito Mussolini: A Guide to the Biographical Literature |journal=Journal of Modern History |volume=35 |issue= |pages=345 |publisher= |doi= 10.1086/243817|url= |accessdate= }} A more appreciative assessment said ''Freedom of the Press'' was "one-sided, but well deserves careful reading."{{cite encyclopedia |last=Langer |first=William W. |year=1936 |title=Some Recent Books on International Relations |encyclopedia=Foreign Affairs |publisher=Council on Foreign Relations |url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/20030753?uid=3738880&uid=2460338415&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&uid=83&uid=63&sid=21104677507847 |accessdate=September 24, 2014 |volume=14 |location= |id= |pages=358}} Summing up Seldes's work, another wrote that "until 1947 [Seldes] followed the Stalinist line so closely that any author must use him with the utmost care."{{cite journal |last1=Doenecke |first1=Justus D. |last2=Edwards |first2=John Carver |year=1992 |title=Berlin Calling: American Broadcasters in Service to the Third Reich |journal=International History Review |volume=14 |issue=600–2 |pages= |publisher=Taylor & Francis |location=London |doi= 10.2307/40106635|url=https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/40106635?uid=3738880&uid=2460338415&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&uid=83&uid=63&sid=21104677507847 |accessdate=September 24, 2014}} [[A. J. Liebling]] said on him, "[George Seldes is] about as subtle as a house falling in. He makes too much of the failure of newspapers to print exactly what George Seldes would have printed if he were the managing editor. But he is a useful citizen. In fact is a fine little gadfly, representing an enormous effort for one man and his wife".{{cite web |url=http://www.brasscheck.com/seldes/bio.html |title=The Forgotten Man of American Journalism: A Brief Biography of George Seldes |last1=Holhut |first1=Randolph T. |website= |publisher=Brasscheck |accessdate=August 20, 2013 |quote='He's about as subtle as a house falling in', wrote fellow press critic A.J. Liebling in his classic 1947 book, 'The Wayward Pressman'. 'He makes too much of the failure of newspapers to print exactly what George Seldes would have printed if he were the managing editor. But he is a useful citizen. (In fact) is a fine little gadfly, representing an enormous effort for one man and his wife'.}} But a whole generation of journalists and activists were influenced greatly by Seldes. Long-time ''Washington Post'' columnist [[Colman McCarthy]] said, "He was a reporter who didn't worry about being objective. He worried about what he would choose to write. I'm always amused when they call somebody 'one-sided'. Seldes offered one side – the side you weren't getting elsewhere".{{cite news |title=George Seldes: Giant of Journalism |first=Colman |last=McCarthy |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/18603769.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jul+11%2C+1995&author=Colman+McCarthy&desc=George+Seldes%3A+Giant+of+Journalism |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=July 11, 1995 |accessdate=September 1, 2011}} Nader said of Seldes, "He was like a doctor. He reported about disease in the political economy, and the gross inequities of power, and the abuses and the exploitation. I always wanted to be a crusading lawyer, and he gave me some materials to contemplate crusading about." Journalist [[Nat Hentoff]] said, "He took what should be the most honorable term in journalism – muckraking – and made it work again. A lot of journalists of his generation and the generation or two that followed, did more, took risks, because [Seldes] was the model. And the fact that he was there made them feel like whores if they didn't do more." People such as [[Peggy Charren]]{{cite news |title=Children's Crusade Has a Happy Ending |first=Colman |last=McCarthy |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/washingtonpost/access/73987498.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jan+28%2C+1992&author=COLMAN+McCARTHY&pub=The+Washington+Post+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&edition=&startpage=d.14&desc=Children%27s+Crusade+Has+a+Happy+Ending |newspaper=The Washington Post |date=January 28, 1992 |accessdate=September 1, 2011}} and [[I. F. Stone]] also claimed influence from Seldes. ==Works== {{refbegin|2}} * {{cite book |title=You Can't Print That!: The Truth Behind the News, 1918–1928 |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1929 |publisher=Payson & Clarke Ltd |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006068415 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Can These Things Be! |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1931 |publisher=Brewer, Warren & Putnam |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000399894 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=World Panorama: 1918–1933 |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1933 |publisher=Little, Brown and Company |location=Boston |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000399897 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=The Vatican: Yesterday – Today – Tomorrow |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1934 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} * {{cite book |title=Iron, Blood, and Profits: An Exposure of the World-wide Munitions Racket |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1934 |publisher=Harper |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001621838 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Sawdust Caesar: The Untold History of Mussolini and Fascism |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1935 |publisher=Harper |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/005919908 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Freedom of the Press |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1935 |publisher=The Bobbs-Merrill Company |location=Indianapolis |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001901574 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Lords of the Press |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1938 |publisher=J. Messner, Inc |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006673736 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=You Can't Do That |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1938 |publisher=Modern Age Books |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000577354 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=The Catholic Crisis |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1939 |publisher=J. Messner, Inc |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/006574897 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Witch Hunt: The Technique and Profits of Redbaiting |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1940 |publisher=Modern Age Books |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001434410 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=The Facts Are: A Guide to Falsehood and Propaganda in the Press and Radio |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1942 |publisher=In Fact, Inc |location=New York |isbn= |url=https://archive.org/details/factsareguidetof00seldrich |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Facts and Fascism |last=Seldes |first=George |author2=Seldes, Helen |year=1943 |publisher=In Fact, Inc |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000465829 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=One Thousand Americans: The Real Rulers of the U.S.A. |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1947 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} * {{cite book |title=The People Don't Know: The American Press and the Cold War |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1949 |publisher=Gaer Associates |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/000808911 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Tell the Truth and Run |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1953 |publisher=Greenberg |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001439589 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=The Great Quotations |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1960 |publisher=L. Stuart |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001003640 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Never Tire of Protesting |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1968 |publisher=L. Stuart |location=New York |isbn= |url=http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/010097720 |accessdate=August 31, 2011}} * {{cite book |title=Even the Gods Can't Change History |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1976 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} * {{cite book |title=The Great Thoughts |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1985 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} * {{cite book |title=Witness to a Century: The Noted, the Notorious, and Three S.O.B.s |last=Seldes |first=George |year=1987 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} {{refend}} ==Footnotes== :aa. {{note|aaa}} Asked how to say his name, he told the ''[[Literary Digest]]'' in 1936: "Nine persons out of ten mispronounce our name. If it had an ''n'' instead of an ''s'' as the final letter there would be no difficulty. The name is pronounced like ''Selden'' with the last letter an ''s''": {{respell|SEL|dəs}}. :ab. {{note|aab}} According to Minton the Party wanted an American version of [[Claud Cockburn]]'s muckraking London political weekly, ''[[The Week (1933)|The Week]]''. ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |last = Fordham |first = Helen |date = November 17, 2016 |title = Subversive Voices: George Seldes and Mid-Twentieth-Century Muckraking |url = http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/08821127.2016.1241643 |journal = American Journalism |volume = 33 |issue = 4 |pages = 424–441 |doi = 10.1080/08821127.2016.1241643 |access-date = January 29, 2017}} * {{cite book |title=The George Seldes Reader |last=Holhut |first=Randolph T. |year=1994 |publisher= |location= |isbn= |url= |accessdate=}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=George Seldes |sopt=t}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Seldes, George}} [[Category:1890 births]] [[Category:1995 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century American non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American alternative journalists]] [[Category:American anti-fascists]] [[Category:American centenarians]] [[Category:American freelance journalists]] [[Category:American investigative journalists]] [[Category:American media critics]] [[Category:American newspaper journalists]] [[Category:American people of Russian-Jewish descent]] [[Category:American people of the Spanish Civil War]] [[Category:American people of World War I]] [[Category:American war correspondents]] [[Category:Chicago Tribune people]] [[Category:George Polk Award recipients]] [[Category:Jewish American journalists]] [[Category:Jewish American writers]] [[Category:Newsletter publishers (people)]] [[Category:Religious skeptics]] [[Category:United Press International]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Greg Graffin |image = Greg Graffin-Starland BallRoom-2007.jpg |caption = Greg Graffin on stage with Bad Religion in 2007 at the [[Starland Ballroom]] in [[Sayreville, New Jersey]] |image_size = |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Gregory Walter Graffin |alias = |birth_date ={{Birth date and age|1964|11|6|mf=y}} |birth_place =[[Madison, Wisconsin]], [[U.S.]] |death_date = |instrument = Vocals, guitar, piano, harmonica, synthesizer, drums |genre = [[Punk rock]], [[hardcore punk]], [[folk music|folk]] |occupation = Musician, singer-songwriter, lecturer, producer, author |years_active = c. 1979–present |label = [[Epitaph Records|Epitaph]], [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], [[ANTI-]] |associated_acts = [[Bad Religion]] |website = }}
'''Gregory Walter Graffin''' (born November 6, 1964) is an American [[punk rock]] singer-songwriter, multi-instrumentalist, college lecturer, and author. He is most recognized as the lead vocalist, songwriter, and only constant member of the noted Los Angeles band [[Bad Religion]], which he co-founded in either 1979 or 1980. He also embarked on a solo career in 1997, when he released the album ''[[American Lesion]]''. His follow-up album, ''[[Cold as the Clay]]'' was released nine years later. Graffin obtained his PhD in the [[history of science]] at [[Cornell University]] and has lectured courses in [[natural sciences]] at both the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] and at [[Cornell University]].
==Career with Bad Religion== In 1979, at the age of 15, Greg Graffin and a few high school classmates formed Bad Religion in Southern California's [[San Fernando Valley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebrpage.net/news/?newsID=1837 |title=Report from Amsterdam 6/11/2010 | News from the front | The Bad Religion Page - Since 1995 |publisher=Thebrpage.net |date= |accessdate=2013-12-06}}</ref> After making a name for themselves in the Los Angeles punk scene, releasing two EPs and two full-length albums, they disbanded around 1985. However, Bad Religion reformed in 1986 with a new line-up, consisting of Graffin on vocals, [[Brett Gurewitz]] and [[Greg Hetson]] on guitars, [[Jay Bentley]] on bass, and [[Pete Finestone]] on drums. In 1988, they released ''[[Suffer (album)|Suffer]]'', which was a comeback for Bad Religion as well as a watershed for the Southern [[California punk]] sound popularized by guitarist Gurewitz's [[Epitaph Records]]. The reunion line-up made two more records before Finestone left the band in 1991.
Bad Religion has been known for its articulate and often politically charged lyrics as well as its fast-paced [[harmony]], [[melody]] and [[counterpoint]]. Graffin and Gurewitz are the band's two main songwriters, though Graffin wrote the bulk of the material on his own for a three-album period in the late 1990s. Gurewitz had left the band in 1994 to concentrate on the future of Epitaph.
After a stint with major label [[Atlantic Records]] ended in the early 2000s, Bad Religion re-signed with Epitaph and Gurewitz rejoined. They have since continued to co-write songs and recorded five records: ''[[The Process of Belief]]'' (2002), ''[[The Empire Strikes First]]'' (2004), ''[[New Maps of Hell (Bad Religion album)|New Maps of Hell]]'' (2007), ''[[The Dissent of Man]]'' (2010)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebrpage.net/news/?newsID=1840 |title=New album title revealed! |publisher=Thebrpage.net |date= |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> and the latest, ''[[True North (album)|True North]]'' (2013).
==Solo career== Graffin recorded a solo album in 1997, called ''[[American Lesion]]'', which consisted of softer, more pop-oriented folk songs. Most of this album was written during the breakup of his marriage, and the songs reflect this in lyrics and style.
In 2005, Graffin recorded his second solo album ''[[Cold as the Clay]].'' The album is an amalgamation of new songs by Graffin and 18th- and 19th-century American folk songs. It was produced by [[Brett Gurewitz]] and released on ANTI- Records on July 10, 2006.
In a September 2015 interview, Graffin revealed that he has been working on his third solo album, which will continue the folk style of his previous album ''Cold as the Clay''. His latest record, "Millport" was released on March 10, 2017. It was co-written and produced by Brett Gurewitz of Bad Religion and features members of Social Distortion as backing musicians.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebrpage.net/news/?newsID=2151 |title=New solo album Greg Graffin? |publisher=The Bad Religion Page |date=26 September 2015 |accessdate=2 October 2015}}</ref>
==Academia== Graffin attended [[El Camino Real High School]], then obtained both his bachelor's and master's at the [[University of California, Los Angeles]] (UCLA). He went on to earn his PhD in the [[history of science]] from [[Cornell University]]. The PhD dissertation was supervised by [[William B. Provine]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Graffin|first=Greg|title=The Cornell Evolution Project |url=http://www.polypterus.com/|accessdate=June 5, 2013}}</ref> After years of being out-of-print, the title of his dissertation changed to "Evolution and Religion: Questioning the Beliefs of the World's Eminent Evolutionists".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://catalog.library.cornell.edu/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?BBID=5077552 |title= Cornell University Library Catalog}}</ref>
Greg Graffin returned to UCLA where he taught natural science courses.<ref name="Reading">{{cite web|last=Feinberg|first=Paul|title=Reading, Writing and Rock 'n' Roll|url=http://magazine.ucla.edu/exclusives/bad-religion_greg-graffin/|publisher=UCLA Magazine|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref> In a June 2008 interview with Bad Religion bassist [[Jay Bentley]], he mentioned that Graffin would be teaching there from January to March 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.punknews.org/article/29193 |title=Bad Religion looks ahead to 2009 album |publisher=Punknews.org|accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref> In April 2011, Graffin revealed that he would return to [[Cornell University]] that fall to co-teach for 14 weeks.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebrpage.net/news/?newsID=1913 |title=UPDATE: Bad Religion to be playing the Punk Rock Holiday Festival|publisher=Thebrpage.net |accessdate=2012-05-12}}</ref>
==Work as an author and educator of naturalism and atheism== Greg Graffin received the Rushdie Award for Cultural Humanism from the Harvard Humanist Chaplaincy in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|title=Greg Graffin (Bad Religion) talks about humanist award|url=http://www.punknews.org/article/28963|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Greg Graffin's Lifetime Achievement Award Acceptance Speech|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w5j9YxpGIPs|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref> [[File:Greg Graffin of Bad Religion sings the National Anthem at the Reason Rally. National Mall, Washington, DC, 2012.jpg|thumb|Greg Graffin of Bad Religion sings the National Anthem at the Reason Rally. National Mall, Washington, DC, 2012]] Throughout 2003, Graffin was engaged in an ongoing email discussion with Preston Jones, a historian at the Christian [[John Brown University]] in [[Arkansas]] and fan of Bad Religion. The informal philosophical debate that resulted was published as a book titled ''Is Belief in God Good, Bad or Irrelevant? A Professor and Punk Rocker Discuss Science, Religion, Naturalism & Christianity'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|author=tor on |url= http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2007/08/greg-graffin-punkrock-phd.html|title=Greg Graffin: Punk-Rock Ph.D.|publisher=Pastemagazine.com |date= |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.punknews.org/review/6278 |title=Preston Jones / Greg Graffin – Is Belief in God Good, Bad or Irrelevant?|publisher= Punknews.org|accessdate=2012-05-12}}</ref>
In 2009 Graffin announced that he had co-written a book with American author [[Steve Olson (writer)|Steve Olson]] titled ''Anarchy Evolution'', released on September 28, 2010 (the same day his band Bad Religion released their 15th album ''[[The Dissent of Man]]'').<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thebrpage.net/news/?newsID=1618 |title=Graffins new book | News from the front | The Bad Religion Page – Since 1995 |publisher=Thebrpage.net |date= |accessdate=2010-10-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Anarchy Evolution|publisher=Amazon.ca |date=September 28, 2010 |id= {{ASIN|0061828505|country=ca}}}}</ref> In his book, Graffin writes that he is an [[atheism|atheist]]: "I’ve never believed in God, which technically makes me an atheist".<ref>{{aut|Graffin, Greg & Olson, Steve}}, Anarchy Evolution: Faith, Science, and Bad Religion in a World Without God. It Books, September 20, 2010. {{ISBN|978-0061828508}}</ref> Although Graffin is not religious, he prefers to identify as a [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalist]] rather than as an atheist. "Naturalism is a belief system. A lot of scientists bristle at that. We all have to believe we can find the truth. Evidence is my guide. I rely on observation, experimentation and verification."<ref>{{cite web|last=Draper|first=Electra|title=For punk rocker and professor, Greg Graffin, faith's in the fossil|url=http://www.denverpost.com/news/ci_16600583|publisher=[[The Denver Post]]|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref> He also filmed and co-produced a television pilot called ''Punk Professor''.
In 2010, he commented on the project, "It's sitting on someone's shelf waiting to be developed. I'm not actually pursuing it. I said, yeah, I'll shoot the pilot, then it's out of my hands."<ref>{{cite web|last=Chaplinsky|first=Joshua|title=The Naturalistic Worldview of a Punk Rock Professor|url=http://chuckpalahniuk.net/interviews/musicians/greg-graffin-of-bad-religion|publisher=The Cult: The Official [[Chuck Palahniuk]] Website|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref>
On March 24, 2012, Bad Religion headlined the [[Reason Rally]] in Washington, D.C., where Graffin performed the [[The Star-Spangled Banner|U.S. national anthem]].<ref>{{cite news|url= http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2012/03/reason-rally-bad-religion-washington-dc.html |title=Bad Religion in lineup for March 24 Reason Rally in Washington, D.C. |publisher=The Los Angeles Times |date=March 21, 2012 |accessdate=2012-04-05}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The Reason Rally Official Schedule|url=http://reasonrally.org/official-schedule/|accessdate=June 23, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617121719/http://reasonrally.org/official-schedule/|archivedate=June 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Another book, entitled ''The Population Wars'', was released in September 2015. It had been in works since at least April 2011 and Graffin spoke about it to be "a bit more in depth about the process of evolution".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ithaca.com/entertainment/punk-rock-paleontologist-greg-graffin-pursues-music-and-science/article_f9ddc028-6b6f-11e0-be40-001cc4c002e0.html |title=Punk rock paleontologist: Greg Graffin pursues music and science|publisher= Ithaca Times|accessdate=2016-05-20}}</ref> In a November 2015 interview with ''[[PopMatters]]'' [[journalist]] J.C. Maçek III for Graffin's book ''Population Wars'', Graffin stated "I’ve made a lot of mistakes, but you can’t dwell on mistakes because life is about an adventure. It’s about discovery. And you learn from your mistakes so unless you’re completely shut down to improving your life, I believe you can continue learning until you’re very, very old. You have to look at those past missteps as learning experiences."<ref name=PM>{{cite web|work=[[PopMatters]]|author=Maçek III, J.C.|url=http://www.popmatters.com/feature/adventure-and-discovery-an-academic-discussion-with-bad-religions-greg-graf/|title=Adventure and Discovery, An Academic Discussion With Bad Religion's Greg Graffin|date=24 November 2015}}</ref>
